On March 12, 2012, a group of twenty leading Russian [[philosophy|philosophers]], [[Oriental studies|orientologists]], and [[philology|philologists]] published an open letter addressing both [[President of the Russian Federation|Russian President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] and the [[Prime Minister of Russia|Russian Prime Minister]] and [[President-elect]] [[Vladimir Putin]], with copies sent to Russia's [[Prosecutor General of Russia|Presecutor General]], [[Ministry of Justice of Russia|Ministry of Justice]], and [[Public Chamber]], urging the ruling tandem to take the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' court case under their "personal control".<ref name=Hindu-20>{{cite news|last=Radyushin|first=Vladimir|title=Russian scholars' plea on Gita|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2999643.ece|accessdate=16 March 2012|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=15 March 2012|location=Chennai, India}}</ref><ref name=Newsru-20>{{cite news|script-title=ru:Российские ученые просят Медведева и Путина взять процесс над "Бхагавад-гитой" под личный контроль|trans-title=Russian scholars ask Medvedev and Putin to take "Bhagavad Gita" court case under their personal control|url=http://newsru.com/religy/15mar2012/bhagavad.html|accessdate=16 March 2012|newspaper=[[NEWSru]]|date=15 March 2012|language=Russian}}</ref> The scholars said they were alarmed by the Tomsk prosecutor's attempting to overrule the earlier court's rejection of the extremest charges against the book, and filing a modified petition asking the court to ban only Bhaktivedanta Swami's commentaries and exempting the original text from the charges of extremism. The scholars criticized the prosecutor's indictment of the commentaries with extremism as "untrue and contrary to the traditions of Hinduism".<ref name=Hindu-20 /> They emphasized that, contrary to the prosecutor's accusations, the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' was considered sacred by a section of Hindu followers as belonging to the commentary tradition of [[Gaudiya Vaishnavism|Bengali Vaishnavism]], "one of the most popular branches of Hinduism",<ref name=Hindu-20 /> and "did not contain any signs of extremism and did not incite hatred on ethnic, religious or any other grounds".<ref name=Hindu-20 /> The scholars also warned Russia's top leaders that the trial "discredits Russia's cultural and democratic credentials in the eyes of the civilized world and is driving a wedge in Russian-Indian relations".<ref name=Hindu-20 />
===ISKCON=== Maxim Osipov, a representative of ISKCON's [[Governing Body Commission]], said that the commentary to ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' is "a precise and clear reflection" on the religious tradition taught by Prabhupada, the founder-[[acharya]] of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness.<ref name=RAPSI-Conf />
==Reaction to the court decision==
===In India=== {{Expand section|date=March 2012}}
"I welcome the verdict of the Honourable District Court in Tomsk today, which has dismissed the appeal petition in the ''Bhagavad Gita'' case. It is good that the decision of the lower trial court in this matter has been reaffirmed. I trust that this issue is now conclusively behind us", said [[Ajai Malhotra]], Indian Ambassador to the Russian Federation.<ref name=RIR-Mar21>{{cite news|title=Tomsk court dismisses Bhagavad Gita case|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2012/03/21/tomsk_court_dismisses_bhagavad_gita_case_15204.html|date=21 March 2012}}</ref>
"We appreciate this sensible resolution of a sensitive issue and are glad to put this episode behind us. We also appreciate the efforts of all friends in Russia who made this outcome possible. This demonstrates yet again that the people of India and Russia have a deep understanding of each other’s cultures and will always reject any attempt to belittle our common civilizational values", said Indian foreign ministry spokesman Vishnu Prakash.<ref name=AP /><ref name=HTx />
===In Russia=== {{expand section|date=April 2012}}
====Human Rights Commissioner==== {{expand section|date=April 2012}} On April 11, 2012 [[Vladimir Lukin]], the [[Human Rights]] [[Commissioner]] of Russia, "warned against court decisions on ''Bhagavad Gita'' texts based on judges' opinions rather than expert examinations." Lukin stated that the "Tomsk [judges] considered something they should not have… It should have been up to [[theologian]]s and [[historian]]s." Lukin noted that "[[Winston Churchill]] once said: Stupidity is also a gift of God, but one mustn't misuse it."<ref name=dailymail-Lukin>{{cite news|title=Russian ombudsman warns Gita rulings should be up to experts|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2128403/Russian-ombudsman-warns-Gita-rulings-experts.html|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=11 April 2012|location=London|first=Dadan|last=Upadhyay}}</ref><ref name=IT-Lukin>{{cite news|title=Russian ombudsman warns on Gita rulings|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/russian-ombudsman-warns-on-gita-rulings/1/184131.html|newspaper=[[India Today]]|date=12 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=RIA-Lukin>{{cite news|title=Bhagavad Gita Texts Up for Experts to Judge - Russian Ombudsman|url=http://en.ria.ru/society/20120411/172744774.html|newspaper=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=11 April 2012}}</ref>
====Religions==== On December 28, 2011, the day the Tomsk court dismissed extremism charges against the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'', director of the Human Rights Center of the World Russian People's Council [[Roman Silantyev]] said that the examination of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'' as extremist was accurate, and that "it has nothing to do with traditional Hinduism."
He also called Krishna devotees in Russia marginal pseudo-Hindu cult members with "extremely nasty reputation" and condemned their [[Hare Krishna Food for Life|charitable food distribution programs]] saying it was unacceptable for Orthodox, Muslim, Jews and Buddhist believers.<ref name=IFSil>{{cite news|title=Tomsk court didn't find "Bhagavad Gita" translation extremist|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=8953|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=28 December 2011|agency=[[Interfax]]}}</ref>
On January 18, 2012, a number of Russia's Islamic leaders denounced Hare Krishna followers in Russia as a "destructive cult" and called on the Russian authorities not to yield to the Indian pressure in regard of the proposed banning of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It''. [[Mufti]] Muhammedgali Huzin, head of All-Russian Muslim Board executive committee, said, "I believe that Russian authorities should be principally tough in the question and shouldn't give way to any provocations and pressure. I think that Russia can do without semiliterate interpretations of ancient epos". First deputy chairman of the Central Spiritual Board of Russian Muslims Mufti of Moscow and Russia's Central Region Albir Krganov proposed to "pay the debt" to Krishna devotees in Russia for their charitable food distribution by "delivering nutritious Halal canned beef to starving Krishna devotees of India. We are ready to personally distribute this meat to Russian Krishnaites".<ref name=IF-Mus>{{cite news|title=Russian Muslims believe Krishnaites a sect and ready to deliver them Halal meat|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=8986|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=18 January 2012|agency=[[Interfax]]}}</ref><ref name=RIR-Appeal>{{cite news|title=Siberian prosecutors make another attempt to ban Prabhupada’s Gita interpretation|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2012/01/26/siberian_prosecutors_make_another_attempt_to_ban_prabhupadas_gita_in_14630.html|accessdate=16 February 2012|newspaper=Russia & India Report|date=26 January 2012}}</ref> However, other all-Russia Islamic umbrella organizations rejected their statements as "fortunately" not representing the opinion of a majority of Russian Muslims of the issue.<ref name=RIR-Appeal />
On January 27, 2012, a group of Russian Orthodox Christian activists entered the premises of the Moscow Krishna temple and tried to hand the temple authorities a box of canned beef. The group claimed that their action was in retaliation for the burning of the Russian flag in India by Hindu fundamentalists protesting the proposed ban of the ''Bhagavad Gita As It Is'', which they called an "anti-Russian … disgraceful act" and "one of the steps in the unprecedented campaign of pressing on Russian court".<ref>{{cite news|title=Orthodox believers conveyed a batch of tinned stewed meat to Moscow Krishnaites in protest against burning Russian flag|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=9015|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=27 January 2012}}</ref>
On January 31, 2012, the head of the Traditional Buddhist Sangha of Russia Andrey Baljirov called the Indian authorities who asked the Russian government to help avert the proposed ban of the Bhagavad Gita As It Is "misinformed" and "exerting pressure" and spoke against the proposed construction of the Krishna temple in Moscow because "there are Buddhist followers in Moscow who do not have a temple yet".<ref name=IF-Bud>{{cite news|script-title=ru:В буддийской общине РФ выступают против строительства храма кришнаитов в Москве|trans-title=The Buddhist community of Russia spoke against the construction of Krishna temple in Moscow|url=http://www.interfax-religion.ru/?act=news&div=44000|accessdate=16 February 2012|date=31 January 2012|agency=[[Interfax]]|language=Russian}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Federal List of Extremist Materials]] * [[Freedom of the press in the Russian Federation]] * [[Hinduism in Russia#Controversy over construction of a Hindu temple in Moscow|Controversy over construction of a Hindu temple in Moscow]] * [[Frivolous litigation]]

{{Infobox person | name = Abby Scott Baker | image = Abby Scott Baker detail.png | caption = Abby Scott Baker circa 1916 | birth_date = July 24, 1871 | birth_place = [[Louisville, Kentucky]], US | death_date = May 13, 1944 (aged 72) | death_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], US | occupation = [[Suffragist]] | parents = | relatives = | alma mater = }}
'''Abby Pearce Scott Baker''' (1871 – 1944) was an American [[suffragist]] and women's rights advocate.<ref>[http://memory.loc.gov/ammem/collections/suffrage/nwp/profiles4.html Library of Congress: Photographs from the Records of the National Woman's Party]. Accessed 22 September 2013</ref> She served as Political Chairman of the [[National Woman's Party]], and played a key role in putting the NWP in the media spotlight in the months leading up to the ratification of [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].<ref name="milcit">{{cite book | last = Southard | first = Belinda A. Stillion | authorlink = | title = Militant Citizenship: Rhetorical Strategies of the National Woman's Party, 1913-1920 | publisher = [[Texas A&M University Press]] | series = | volume = | edition = | date = | location = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-FUYTHpK4LMC | doi = | id = | isbn = 9781603442824 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = | year = 2011 }}</ref> She was also active in the [[Congressional Union|Congressional Union for Women's Suffrage]].<ref>{{cite book | last =Darrow | first =Clarence | authorlink = | title =In the Clutches of the Law: Clarence Darrow's Letters | publisher =[[University of California Press]] | series = | volume = | edition = | year =2013 | location = | pages =278 | language = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=XDZs6AsRFQsC | doi = | id = | isbn =9780520265585 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref> Baker was seen as instrumental in bridging the gap across administrations, from [[Woodrow Wilson]], who was deeply hostile toward the NWP, to Harding, who was seen as more willing to engage the NWP in dialogue, and brought women's participation in party politics to a more acceptable place in the public discourse.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | coauthors = | title =Woman Threatens Wilson | newspaper =[[New York Times]] | location =New York City | pages = | publisher = | date =1918-01-03 | url =https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1918/01/03/102651505.pdf | accessdate = 2013-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last =Schrems | first =Suzanne H. | authorlink = | title =Who's Rocking the Cradle?: Women Pioneers of Oklahoma Politics from Socialism to the KKK, 1900-1930 | publisher =Horse Creek Publications | series = | volume = | edition = | year =2004 | location = | pages =47 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=IxiPmk6scMAC | doi = | id = | isbn =9780972221726 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}</ref>
==Biography== She was born on July 24, 1871, as '''Abby Pearce Scott''' in [[Louisville, Kentucky]], to Robert Nicholson Scott (1838–1887) and Elizabeth Goodale Casey (1844–1912). Her father and grandfather were Army officers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I2BJygCeSLQC&pg=PA352&dq=Abby+Scott+Baker+sons&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi_7p7GiaPQAhVDfiYKHQbXBCkQ6AEILjAD#v=onepage&q=Abby%20Scott%20Baker%20sons&f=false|title=American Feminism: Key Source Documents, 1848-1920|last=Beer|first=Janet|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=9780415219457|language=en}}</ref>
She was educated at the Norwood Institute.
She married Robert Walker Baker (1863–1956) around 1893. The couple had three sons.<ref name=":0" />
== Suffrage activist == Bakers was one of [[Alice Paul]]’s earliest associates. She helped Alice Paul and [[Lucy Burns]] plan their first major event–the March 3, 1913, national suffrage parade on the eve of Woodrow Wilson’s inauguration.<ref name="bio" />
In 1914 she served as treasurer of the [[Congressional Union for Woman Suffrage]].<ref name="bio">{{cite web |url=https://www.loc.gov/collections/static/women-of-protest/articles-and-essays/selected-leaders-of-the-national-womans-party/lobbyists.html |title=Abby Scott Baker (1871-1944) |date= |accessdate=2014-07-23 |quote= |publisher= |location= }}</ref>
Baker traveled the country as part of the Congressional Union’s “Suffrage Special” train tour of western states in April–May 1916. Baker was in charge of handling the press for the tour. The support that she helped raise from women in states that had already granted women’s suffrage.<ref name="bio" /> On April 29, Baker wrote to ''The Suffragist'' on how the tour was received '[Men] invariably call out, 'Here come the Suffragettes,' but very soon they are saying, 'She's all right,' and 'That's straight lady,' or some such approving phrase..."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924030480556/cu31924030480556_djvu.txt|title=Full text of "The story of the Woman's Party"|website=archive.org|access-date=2016-11-12}}</ref> The tour culminated in a June 1916 meeting in Chicago to form what was at first called the Woman’s Party of Western Voters, or Woman’s Party, for short (NWP). When the NWP was more formally organized in relation to the CU in March 1917, Baker was elected to the NWP executive committee and served as its press chairman (1917-18) and political chairman (1917; 1919-21).<ref name="bio" />
Baker was among the first demonstrators to picket the White House; she was arrested in September 1917 and sentenced to 60 days in the [[Lorton Reformatory|Occoquan Workhouse]]. In February–March 1919, she served as publicity manager and speaker for the “Prison Special,” a three-week lecture tour by NWP activists who spoke to packed audiences about their jail experiences in an effort to generate support for the suffrage cause.<ref name="bio" /> The other speakers included [[Lillian Ascough]], [[Harriot Stanton Blatch]] and [[Lucy Burns]]. They spoke publicly, distributed literature, and sold the [[The Suffragist|''Suffragist''.]] This tour was credited with arousing interest in federal suffrage among, prospective, voting age women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://groups.ischool.berkeley.edu/archive/suffragists/SuffragistsSpeak/1916.html|title=Suffragists Timeline: 1916|website=groups.ischool.berkeley.edu|access-date=2018-08-04}}</ref>
When the NWP’s patriotism was challenged, she reminded critics that her three sons were fighting in World War I.<ref name="bio" />
Baker maintained an intense travel schedule before and during the campaign season for the [[United States presidential election, 1920|1920 presidential election]], shuttling between the campaign headquarters of [[Warren G. Harding]] in Ohio and [[James M. Cox]] in Tennessee, building close relationships with both candidates. Baker's indefatigable efforts drew a great deal of media attention, and helped to normalize the presence of women in the political sphere in the public imagination.<ref name="milcit" />
== Later life == After suffrage was achieved, Baker became a member of the NWP’s Committee on International Relations and the Women’s Consultative Committee of the League of Nations. She also represented the NWP at the League’s 1935 international conferences in Geneva where the issue of equal rights was discussed.<ref name="bio" />
She died on May 13, 1944, in [[Washington, DC]].
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Abby Scott Baker}} *{{Find a Grave|95093148}}
{{Suffrage}} {{Feminism}} {{Authority control}}

page.title: Access to public information in Bosnia and Herzegovina

revision.comment: /* Access to public information in practice */ fix
revision.text:
{{See also|Access to public information in Europe}}
'''Access to public information''' and '''[[freedom of information]] (FOI)''' refer to the right to access information held by public bodies also known as "right to know". Access to public information is considered of fundamental importance for the effective functioning of democratic systems, as it enhances governments' and public officials' accountability, boosting people participation and allowing their informed participation into public life. The fundamental premise of the right to access public information is that the information held by governmental institutions is in principle public and may be concealed only on the basis of legitimate reasons which should be detailed in the law.<ref>[http://www.unesco.org/new/en/communication-and-information/freedom-of-expression/freedom-of-information Freedom of Information, UNESCO. {{Retrieved|access-date=2016-10-16}}]</ref>
[[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] was one of the first countries in the Balkans to adopt the Freedom of Access to Information Act, at the State level in 2000, and then in 2001 in both of its entities, namely the [[Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and the [[Republika Srpska]]. However, according to some experts the law requires changes to address a series of shortcomings that have been identified over the years.<ref name=BIRN2016>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 2016 |title=Transparency in the Balkans and Moldova|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/file/show/Transparency-in-the-Balkans-and-Moldova.pdf |publisher=Balkan Investigative Report Network (BIRN) |issue=|access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref name=Analitika>{{cite journal |author= |date=December 2013 |title=Towards Proactive Transparency in Bosnia and Herzegovina|url=http://www.analitika.ba/sites/default/files/publikacije/proaktivna_transparentnost_policy_memo_eng_4juni_web.pdf |publisher=Analitika. Centre for Social Research |issue= Policy Memo |access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref>
==Background== Due to the specific circumstances and the way in which it was created, the Constitution of Bosnia and Herzegovina, annex IV of [[Dayton Agreement|Dayton Peace Agreement]] did not pay much attention to the right to information.<ref name=Internews>{{cite journal |author=Mehmed HALILOVIĆ and Amer DŽIHANA |date=2012 |title=Media Law in Bosnia and Herzegovina |url=http://www.internews.ba/sites/default/files/attachments/Media%20law%20in%20BiH%20eng.pdf |publisher=Internews in Bosnia and Herzegovina |access-date=27 January 2017}}</ref> The development of freedom of information legislation was initiated with a decision of the [[High Representative for Bosnia and Herzegovina|High Representative]] in 1999. The Decision asked the State and the Entities to adopt such a legislation. The consultation process for drafting the law involved the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE)]]’s legal experts and extensive public discussions with citizens and civil society groups. The Act was adopted by the Bosnia and Herzegovina State Government in October 2000, and the Republika Srpska Government in May 2001.<ref name=OSCE2001>{{cite web |url=http://www.osce.org/bih/53670 |title=Freedom of Access to information Law fully adopted in Bosnia and Herzegovina |last= |first= |date=26 June 2001 |website=Osce.org |publisher= Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) |access-date=27 January 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
==Legal framework== The laws establish a general right of the public to access the information held by public authorities/organs “to the greatest extent possible consistent with the public interest”. Therefore, the laws establish a general obligation of making all relevant information public, except for some cases falling under the exceptions defined by the law.<ref name=Internews/> Access to public information applies to information held by all public organs (legislative, judiciary, executive and administrative) and regardless of their format (written documents, digital data, audio or video records, etc.) as well as to legal persons owner or controlled by public bodies, such as public enterprises, public schools, universities, state agencies, etc. On the contrary, it does not apply to private organisations, private companies and the commercial sector.<ref name=Internews/> The laws entitle every person, regardless of his or her citizenship, nationality, ethnicity, or place of residence, the right to access to public information. Journalists and media outlet do not have more rights compared with other requesters.<ref name=Internews/> The prescribed period of time for obtaining the requested information is 15 days from the submission of the request.<ref name=Internews/> Under the FOI laws, public authorities are both obliged to provide access to documents and records and to publish the most important information without a request ([[proactive disclosure]]). Rules for proactive publication apply to information on institutions’ budget, regular activities and decision-making.<ref name=Internews/>
===Exceptions=== In line with international standards, access to information laws in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and in Republika Srpska establish that in some cases public information can be withheld on a legal basis. Specifically, three cases of exceptions are foreseen: first, when there is the possibility that disclosing information can cause a significant damage to legitimate functions of the government (national security, defence, monetary policy issues, prevention of crime, etc.); second, the exceptions can be applied to protect commercial interests; and, third, to protect personal interests and privacy of a third party.<ref name=Internews/> The application of these exceptions is not automatic: in effect, in order to reject the application on the basis of the exceptions established in the law, authorities have to make the [[public interest test]], meaning considering whether and how the disclosure of information is harming other protected interests.The public interest test is inspired by the most advanced international standards on the right of access to public information. Compared with similar laws in the [[Western Balkans]], only the laws of [[Access to public information in Serbia|Serbia]] and [[Access to public information in Croatia|Croatia]] prescribe such a test.<ref name=Internews/> Exceptions are applied only after a case-by-case analysis of every case and specific circumstances related to each request. Labeling a whole category of information as exemption is forbidden.<ref name=Internews/>
==Access to public information in practice==
In Bosnia and Herzegovina some NGOs contribute to enforce the law on access to public information as well as to monitor its application and collect relevant data through the submission of FOI requests and the start of appeal procedures. This is the case, for instance, of the [[Balkan Insight|Balkan Investigative Reporting Network]] (BIRN), [[Transparency International]] (Bosnia and Herzegovina), or the Sarajevo-based [[Center for Investigative Journalism (CIN)]].<ref name=OBCT>{{cite web |url=http://www.balcanicaucaso.org/aree/Bosnia-Erzegovina/Il-difficile-accesso-alle-informazioni-in-Bosnia-Erzegovina-177818 |title=Il difficile accesso alle informazioni in Bosnia and Herzegovina |last=Mišeljić |first=Ljupko |date=16 February 2017|website=Balcanicaucaso.org|publisher= Media Centar Sarajevo/Osservatorio Balcani Caucaso Transeuropa|access-date=16 February 2017 |language=Italian}}</ref>
According to a report prepared by the [[Association of journalists of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and the country’s Press Council, the vast majority of Bosnians (around 93%) believe that there are several limitations to the right of access to public information in practice.<ref name=KAS>{{cite web |url=http://www.kas.de/wf/en/71.13562/ |title=Media Freedom in Bosnia and Herzegovina |last= |first= |date=2016 |website=Kas.de |publisher=KAS Media Programme South East Europe |access-date=27 January 2017 |quote=}}</ref> At the same, public opinion in Bosnia and Herzegovina is largely not fully aware of their rights with regard to access to public information.<ref name="OBCT" />
When it comes to the application of the law, problems range from inconsistent interpretation of the law by different public bodies, unwillingness to apply it, to non-harmonisation of FOI laws with other laws.<ref name="KAS" />
Specifically, one of the major deficiency of freedom of information laws in Bosnia and Herzegovina is the weakness of the provisions concerning the appeal procedures in case the request is rejected. The FOI law of the Republika Srpska does not stipulate an appeal procedure at all.<ref name=Internews/> Another problem concerns the lack of compliance with other existing laws that exclude or significantly reduce the right to free access to information in practice both in the Federation and in the Republika Srpska.<ref name=Internews/> Also, experts have identified among the shortcomings hindering the application of FOI laws in Bosnia and Herzegovina the lack of an effective system for monitoring their application. Only a small number of public bodies comply with the obligation to publish the information on the number of received questions related to freedom of information on a regular basis.<ref name=Internews/>
In 2013-16 in order to test the implementation of FOI laws, the [[Balkan Investigative Reporting Network]] (BIRN) submitted a series of requests for accessing documents to different public bodies in the country at all level. Half of BIRN’s requests for information were rejected, while the remaining 50 per cent were only partially granted.<ref name="BIRN2016" />
Also, according to [[Transparency International]] - Bosnia and Herzegovina only 40% of public enterprises in Republika Srpska and 27% in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina provides the requested information within the timeframe established by the law. In 37% of cases examined by Transparency International the fulfillment of the procedure lasts more than one month, even if the law stipulates that the information requested must be provided in maximum 15 days.<ref name=OBCT/>
==See also== * [[Access to public information in Europe]] * [[Freedom of information]] * [[Freedom of information laws by country]] * [[Transparency of media ownership in Europe]] * [[Media of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] * [[Media of Bosnia and Herzegovina#Transparency of media owenrship|Transparency of media ownership in Bosnia and Herzegovina]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Freedom of information| ]] [[Category:Rights]] [[Category:Freedom of speech]] [[Category:Human rights by issue]]
{{Access to public information in Europe}}

revision.comment: I changed the definition. It now states that (1)⇔(2)⇔(3). This is a stronger statement that what was previously given. (2) and (3) consequently belong into the definition. A side effect is that no preference is given to any of the 3 conditions, as should be the case since they are equivalent.
revision.text:
In [[mathematics]], more specifically in [[multilinear algebra]], an '''alternating multilinear map''' is a [[multilinear map]] with all arguments belonging to the same space (e.g., a [[bilinear form]] or a [[multilinear form]]) that is zero whenever any two adjacent arguments are equal.
The notion of '''alternatization''' (or '''alternatisation''' in [[British English]]) is used to derive an alternating multilinear map from any multilinear map with all arguments belonging to the same space.
== Definition ==
A multilinear map of the form <math>f\colon V^n \to W</math> is said to be '''alternating''' if it satisfies the following equivalent conditions: # if there exists <math display="inline">1 \leq i \leq n-1</math> such that <math>x_i = x_{i+1}</math> then <math>f(x_1,\ldots,x_n) = 0</math>.<ref name="Lang-2002">{{harvnb|Lang|2002|pages=511–512}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Bourbaki|2007|p=A III.80, §4}}.</ref> # if there exists <math display="inline">1 \leq i \neq j \leq n</math> such that <math>x_i = x_j</math> then <math>f(x_1,\ldots,x_n) = 0</math>.<ref name="Lang-2002"></ref><ref name="Dummit-Foote-2004">{{harvnb|Dummit|Foote|2004|p=436}}.</ref> # if <math>x_1,\ldots,x_n</math> are [[linearly dependent]] then <math>f(x_1,\ldots,x_n) = 0</math>.
== Example ==
* In a [[Lie algebra]], the [[Lie algebra|Lie bracket]] is an alternating bilinear map.
* The [[determinant]] of a matrix is a multilinear alternating map of the rows or columns of the matrix.
== Properties ==
* If any component ''x<sub>i</sub>'' of an alternating multilinear map is replaced by {{nowrap|''x<sub>i</sub>'' + ''c x<sub>j</sub>''}} for any {{nowrap|''j'' ≠ ''i''}} and ''c'' in the base ring ''R'', then the value of that map is not changed.<ref name="Dummit-Foote-2004"></ref> * Every alternating multilinear map is antisymmetric.<ref>{{harvnb|Rotman|1995|p=235}}.</ref> * If ''n''! is a [[Unit (ring theory)|unit]] in the base ring ''R'', then every antisymmetric ''n''-multilinear form is alternating.
== Alternatization ==
Given a multilinear map of the form <math>f\colon V^n \to W</math>, the alternating multilinear map <math>g\colon V^n \to W</math> defined by <math>g(x_1, \ldots, x_n) := \sum_{\sigma \in S_n} \sgn(\sigma)f(x_{\sigma(1)}, \ldots, x_{\sigma(n)})</math> is said to be the '''alternatization''' of <math>f</math>.
; Properties
* The alternatization of an ''n''-multilinear alternating map is ''n''! times itself. * The alternatization of a [[symmetric map]] is zero. * The alternatization of a [[bilinear map]] is bilinear. Most notably, the alternatization of any [[Chain complex|cocycle]] is bilinear. This fact plays a crucial role in identifying the second [[Cohomology|cohomology group]] of a [[Lattice (group)|lattice]] with the group of alternating [[bilinear form]]s on a lattice.
== See also ==
* [[Alternating algebra]] * [[Bilinear map]] * {{section link|Exterior algebra|Alternating multilinear forms}} * [[Map (mathematics)]] * [[Multilinear algebra]] * [[Multilinear map]] * [[Multilinear form]] * [[Symmetrization]]
== Notes ==
{{Reflist}}
== References ==
*{{Cite book | last = Bourbaki | first = N. | title = Eléments de mathématique | volume = Algèbre Chapitres 1 à 3 | publisher = Springer | year = 2007 | edition = reprint | ref = harv }} *{{Cite book | last1 = Dummit | first1 = David S. | last2 = Foote | first2 = Richard M. | title = Abstract Algebra | edition = 3rd | publisher = Wiley | year = 2004 | ref = harv }} *{{Cite book | last = Lang | first = Serge | title = Algebra | publisher = Springer | series = [[Graduate Texts in Mathematics]] | volume = 211 | edition = revised 3rd | year = 2002 | isbn = 978-0-387-95385-4 | oclc = 48176673 | ref = harv }} *{{Cite book | last = Rotman | first = Joseph J. | title = An Introduction to the Theory of Groups | publisher = Springer | series = Graduate Texts in Mathematics | volume = 148 | edition = 4th | year = 1995 | isbn = 0-387-94285-8 | oclc = 30028913 | ref = harv }}

{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=June 2013}} {{Globalize|date=December 2012}} }} An '''alternative lifestyle''' is a [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] diverse in respect to [[mainstream]] ones, or generally perceived to be outside the cultural [[Norm (sociology)|norm]]. ''Lifestyle'' is a [[media culture]] term derived from the concept of [[style in art]].Bernstein, J. M. ''Introduction'', in [[Adorno]] ''[[Culture industry]]'' p.35 quotation: {{quotation|Diversity is more effectively present in mass media than previously, but this is not an obvious or unequivocal gain. By the late 1950s the homogenization of consciousness had become counterproductive for the purposes of capital expansion; new needs for new commodities had to be created, and this required the reintroduction of the minimal negativity that had been previously eliminated. The cult of the new that had been the prerogative of art throughout the modernist epoch into the period of post-war unification and stabilization has returned to capital expansion from which it originally sprang. But this negativity is neither shocking nor emancipatory since it does not presage a transformation of the fundamental structures of everyday life. On the contrary, through the culture industry capital has co-opted the dynamics of negation both diachronically in its restless production of new and ‘different’ commodities and synchronically in its promotion of alternative ‘life-styles’.
‘Life-styles’, the culture industry’s recycling of style in art, represent the transformation of an aesthetic category, which once possessed a moment of negativity [shocking, emancipatory], into a quality of commodity consumption.}} Usually, but not always, it implies an affinity or identification within some matching [[subculture]] (e.g. [[hippies]], [[Goth subculture|goths]] and [[Punk subculture|punks]]). Some people with alternative lifestyles mix elements from various subcultures ([[grunge]] musicians were often influenced by a mixture of the [[punk subculture|punk]], [[acid rock|hippie]], [[emo]] and [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] subcultures). Not all minority lifestyles are held{{by whom|date=June 2014}} to be "alternative", so the term tends to apply to newer forms of lifestyle, often based upon enlarged freedoms (especially in the sphere of social styles), or a decision to substitute another approach, or to not follow the usual expected path in most societies. == History == Alternative lifestyles and subcultures originated in the 1920s{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?hl=en&lr=&id=f5rLCgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=the+flapper+women&ots=kv9L6jn-h-&sig=8djPjwlb-1GHEYp_SKWp-gpfLsE#v=snippet&q=flapper&f=false|title=Modern women on trial: Sexual transgression in the age of the flapper|last=Bland|first=Lucy|date=2013-09-30|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9781847798961|language=en}}{{better source|date=September 2018}} with the "[[flapper]]" movement, when women cut their hair and skirts short (as a symbol of freedom from oppression and the old way of living). Women in the flapper age were the first large group of females to practice pre-marital sex, dancing, cursing, and driving in modern America without scandal following them.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} A [[Stanford University]] cooperative house, [https://web.archive.org/web/20160730005004/http://web.stanford.edu/group/synergy/ Synergy], was founded in 1972 with the theme of "exploring alternative lifestyles." ==Examples == [[File:1981 Camping. Mobile Homes 54 copy.jpg|thumb|[[Housetrucker]]s. Photo taken at the 1981 [[Nambassa]] 5 day festival]] The following are examples which may{{weasel inline|date=September 2018}}{{better source|date=September 2018}} be considered by some{{who|date=September 2018}}{{why|date=September 2018}}{{when|date=September 2018}} to be alternative lifestyles: * Alternative [[child-rearing]], such as [[homeschooling]], [[coparenting]] and [[home births]] * Restrictive dieting, such as [[veganism]], [[vegetarianism]], [[freeganism]], or [[raw foodism]] * Living in unusual communities, such as [[commune]]s, [[Intentional community|intentional communities]], [[ecovillage]]s, [[off-the-grid]], or the [[tiny house movement]] * Traveling [[subcultures]], including [[lifestyle traveller]]s, [[housetrucker|housetrucking]], and [[New Age travellers|New Age travelling]] * [[Body modification]], including [[tattoos]], [[body piercings]], [[Suspension (body modification)|suspension]], and [[transdermal implants]] * [[Nudism]] and [[clothing optional]] lifestyles * Non-normative sexual lifestyles, such as [[BDSM]], [[polyamory]], [[Swinging (sexual practice)|swinging]], and certain types of [[sexual fetishism]] or [[paraphilia]]{{cite book|last1=Makai|first1=Michael|title=Domination & Submission: The BDSM Relationship Handbook|date=September 2013|publisher=Createspace|isbn=1492775975}} * [[Alternative medicine]] and natural methods of medical care or [[herbal remedies]] as medication * Adherents to alternative [[spirituality|spiritual]] and religious practices, such as [[vampire lifestyle|vampirism]], [[Wicca]], [[Neopaganism]], [[Satanism]], or [[cults]] * Certain religious minorities, such as the [[Amish]] who pursue a non-technological or [[anti-technology]] lifestyle ==See also== * [[Alternative culture]] * [[Bohemianism]] * [[Intentional community]] * [[Intentional living]] * [[Subculture]] * [[Underground culture]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://cgi.stanford.edu/~group-synergy/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=Main.HomePage/ Synergy House at Stanford University] {{DEFAULTSORT:Alternative Lifestyle}} [[Category:Subcultures]] [[Category:Philosophy of life]] [[Category:Deviance (sociology)]]

{{BLP primary sources|date=June 2014}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Anne Fausto-Sterling | image = Ada-Lovelace-Wikithon-2013-14-Anne-Fausto-Sterling.jpg | caption = Fausto-Sterling speaking at the [[Ada Lovelace Day]] [[English Wikipedia]] edit-a-thon at [[Brown University]] in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] on October 15, 2013 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1944|7|30|}} | birth_place = [[Queens, New York]] | death_date = | death_place = | residence = [[Providence, Rhode Island]] | citizenship = | nationality = American | ethnicity = | fields = [[Biology]]
[[Women's studies]] | workplaces = [[Brown University]] | alma_mater = [[Brown University]]
[[University of Wisconsin]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Paula Vogel]]|2004}} | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Anne Fausto-Sterling''' (born July 30, 1944) is the [[Nancy Duke Lewis]] Professor of Biology and Gender Studies at [[Brown University]].{{cite web|title=Anne Fausto-Sterling|url=https://brown.edu/Faculty/COSTS/people/facultypage.php?id=1100924089|publisher=Brown University|accessdate=13 January 2013}} She participates actively in the field of [[sexology]] and has written extensively on the fields of [[Sex differences in humans|biology of gender]], [[sexual identity]], [[gender identity]], and [[gender role]]s. ==Life and career== Fausto-Sterling received her [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[zoology]] from [[University of Wisconsin]] in 1965 and her Ph.D. in [[developmental genetics]] from [[Brown University]] in 1970. She has taught at Brown since earning her Ph.D. and is the Nancy Duke Lewis Professor of Biology and Gender Studies in the Department of Molecular and Cell Biology and Biochemistry there. She has written two books intended for the general audience. The second edition of the first of those books, ''Myths of Gender'', was published in 1992.{{cite book |author=Fausto-Sterling, Anne |title=Myths of gender: biological theories about women and men |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |year=1992 |pages= |isbn=0-465-04792-0 |oclc= |doi=}} Her second book for the general public is ''[[Sexing the Body: Gender Politics and the Construction of Sexuality]]'', published in 2000.{{cite book |author=Fausto-Sterling, Anne |title=Sexing the body: gender politics and the construction of sexuality |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |year=2000 |pages= |isbn=0-465-07714-5 |oclc= |doi=}} She stated that in it she sets out to "convince readers of the need for theories that allow for a good deal of human variation and that integrate the analytical powers of the biological and the social into the systematic analysis of human development." {{anchor|The Five Sexes}}In a paper entitled "The Five Sexes",{{cite journal | author=A. Fausto-Sterling | title=The Five Sexes: Why male and female are not enough |url=http://www.fd.unl.pt/docentes_docs/ma/TPB_MA_5937.pdf | journal=[[The Sciences]] | year=1993|issue=March/April 1993|pages= 20–24}} in which, according to her, "I had intended to be provocative, but I had also written with tongue firmly in cheek."{{cite journal |author=Fausto-Sterling A |title=The five sexes, revisited |journal=The Sciences |volume=40 |issue=4 |pages=18–23 |year=2000 |pmid=12569934 |doi=10.1002/j.2326-1951.2000.tb03504.x |url=http://www.neiu.edu/~lsfuller/5sexesrevisited.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121131920/http://www.neiu.edu/~lsfuller/5sexesrevisited.htm |archivedate=November 21, 2007 |df=mdy-all }} Fausto-Sterling laid out a [[thought experiment]] considering an alternative model of gender containing five sexes: [[male]], [[female]], merm, ferm, and [[Hermaphrodite|herm]]. This thought experiment was interpreted by some as a serious proposal or even a theory; advocates for [[intersex]] people stated that this theory was wrong, confusing and unhelpful to the interests of intersex people. In a later paper ("The Five Sexes, Revisited"), she has acknowledged these objections. Fausto-Sterling serves on the editorial board of the journal ''[[Perspectives in Biology and Medicine]]'' and on the advisory board of the feminist academic journal ''[[Signs (journal)|Signs]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/perspectives-biology-and-medicine/editorial-board|title=Editorial Board {{!}} JHU Press|website=www.press.jhu.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-08-31}}{{Cite news|url=http://signsjournal.org/about-signs/masthead/|title=Masthead|date=2012-08-22|work=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|access-date=2017-08-31|language=en-US}} Fausto-Sterling is married to [[Paula Vogel]], a Yale professor and [[Pulitzer Prize for Drama|Pulitzer-winning playwright]]. Fausto-Sterling's mother, [[Dorothy Sterling]], was a noted writer and historian while her father was also a published writer.{{cite web |title=Paula Vogel, Anne Fausto-Sterling |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2004-09-26 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/26/fashion/weddings/26VOGE.html?ex=1185163200&en=74206651722ac22b&ei=5070 |accessdate=2007-07-21}} ==Case studies== ===Naturalism=== "Of Gender and Genitals" is the third chapter of ''Sexing the Body'' by Fausto-Sterling. The chapter starts with a case study description of [[sickle cell anemia]], including [[hemoglobin]] and the risk of having hemoglobin-S crystallize, which leads to intense pain and potential paralysis in times of stress. The lecture on sickle cell anemia ends with two simple conclusions: the first is that a slight alteration to a DNA sequence will leave major changes to the DNA on the whole; the second is that traits and defects cannot be easily predicted. Fausto-Sterling's data goes on to state that genes alone do not decide phenotypes; phenotypes are instead decided by the environmental and developmental history of the person, in addition to their total genetic endowment. In the same regard, behavior is not solely decided by only genetics.{{cite web|title=Theories of Gender Development (4)|url=http://ckbooks.com/psychology/gender-issues-in-psychology/theories-of-gender-development-4/}} The data further goes on to state that while the number of nerves is decided in the former half of pregnancy, cellular interconnection continues to multiply and grow throughout the first four years of life. In addition, the mind and temperament of an adult is shaped by the environment he or she is raised in. Factors included, physical fitness, nutrition, and interpersonal relations with other people. Through these studies and analytical work, the following four gender development theories of biological determinist, psychoanalytic, social learning, and cognitive development have been devised.{{cite book |chapter=Chapter 3: Of Gender and Genitals |title=Sexing the body: gender politics and the construction of sexuality |location=New York, NY |publisher=Basic Books |year=2000 |pages=44–77}} ===Gender development theory=== Following a summary of the prior, Fausto-Sterling shows her points on the gender development theories by noting how XY and XX chromosomes stay identical up until the 6th week of development in the womb. During these six weeks, the XY/XX embryos develop an indifferent gonad, an extra layer that isn't affected by the chromosome embryo due to their indistinguishable similarity at the time. This external process develops in a similar manner to the various male and female reproductive organs that later develop within the body. By the end of the first month and a half, all embryos would've developed, regardless of gender. In addition, the chromosomes within the cells will have developed different sets of [[Mesonephric duct|mesonephric ducts]] that are indifferent to gender. A set of ducts ultimately becomes the aforementioned reproductive organs based on the sex of the fetus. Once the Y chromosome in the XY embryo triggers, an extensive and lengthy process is detailed on the development of male fetuses. Conversely, far less is known on the development of XX fetuses. What is known about the female XX is that the fetuses produce approximately the same amount of estrogen in comparison to the testosterone production in the male XY. Later down the line of fetus growth, the originally identical genitalia of the two types of fetus will differentiate on the eighth week. In some cases the XY fetus will initially begin to develop female genitals instead of the male penis and scrotum due to a deficiency in [[dihydrotestosterone]].{{cite web|title=Contribution of dihydrotestosterone to male sexual behaviour|url=http://bmj.com/content/310/6990/1289}} After detailing the opinions of John Money and Julianne Imperato-McGuinely on gender identity, Fausto-Sterling concludes with the three influences that affect gender – genetic regulatory information, intrusion from outside the womb, and "chance variation" in development – and two points on sexual development." ===The Standard Model=== Sex and gender are two separate characterizations of people and a standard model exists for both sex and gender. Biology characterizes sex by dimorphism. In other words, people are either male or female and nothing in between. Surgical procedures ensure that people are assigned to one of the two accepted sexes. Gender, separate from sex, is socially constructed by culture. People determine the definition of gender by assigning roles to each gender. For example, generally, males are expected to work and women are expected to stay home and care for their family. By assigning a specific role to a gender, we have created a standard model of what it means to be male or female. In essence, the standard model characterizes by masculinity and femininity and separates nature and nurture. In chapter three of ''Sexing the Body'', "Of Gender and Genitals", Fausto-Sterling criticizes the standard model and the way it impacts those both neither male nor female. She explains that doctors surgically assign infants male or female when they are not born with “normal” genitals. Fausto-Sterling believes that as children grow and become either more masculine or feminine “[[nurture]] matters a great deal more than nature” because it affects the child's inclinations towards becoming hetero- or homo- sexual.{{cite book|last=Fausto Sterling|first=Anne|title=Sexing the Body, Of Gender and Genitals|year=2000|location=New York, NY|publisher=Basic Books}} When doctors studied the spectrum of genders, Sterling criticized that “they never questioned the fundamental assumptions that there are only two sexes, because their goal in studying intersexual was to find out more about normal development.”{{cite book|last=Fausto-Sterling|first=Anne|title=Sexing the Body: Gender Politics and the Construction of Sexuality|year=2000|publisher=Basic Books|location=New York|isbn=0-465-07714-5|page=46}} The doctors’ motives for the research of intersexual show that they promote the standard model for sex and are unwilling to accept the fact that there are different variations of sex.{{cite web|last=Fausto-Sterling|first=Anne|title=Sexuality|url=http://www.annefaustosterling.com/fields-of-inquiry/sexuality/}} Sterling strongly believes that doctors are unethical in that they do not allow variations of sex and immediately assign a sex within a few hours of birth because there is not a way of telling whether the infant will be content with their assigned gender. Furthermore, “whatever treatment they choose…physicians… decide how to manage [[Intersex|intersexuality]] act out of…deeply held beliefs about male and female sexuality [and] gender roles.”{{cite book|last=Fausto-Sterling|first=Anne|title=Sexing the Body: Gender Politics and the Construction of Sexuality|year=2000|publisher=Basic Books|location=New York|isbn=0-465-07714-5|page=48}} Sterling argues that the consequence of performing sexual reassignment surgery on intersex infants “[develops] a language that reinforces the idea that lurking inside the mixed-sex child is a real male or female body.”{{cite book|last=Fausto-Sterling|first=Anne|title=Sexing the Body: Gender Politics and the Construction of Sexuality|year=2000|publisher=Basic Books|location=New York|isbn=0-465-07714-5|page=76}} She claims that this is unacceptable because now that society vehemently believes that only males or females should exist,{{cite journal | last = Fausto-Sterling | first = Anne | title = The five sexes: why male and female are not enough | journal = [[The Sciences]] | pages = 20–24 | publisher = [[New York Academy of Sciences]] via [[Wiley-Blackwell|Wiley]] | doi = 10.1002/j.2326-1951.1993.tb03081.x | date = March–April 1993 | url = http://capone.mtsu.edu/phollowa/5sexes.html | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [http://www.fd.unl.pt/docentes_docs/ma/TPB_MA_5937.pdf Pdf.] a window to a spectrum of genders closes.{{cite web|last=Fausto-Sterling|first=Ann|title=The Five Sexes Revisited|url=http://www.neiu.edu/~lsfuller/5sexesrevisited.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071121131920/http://www.neiu.edu/~lsfuller/5sexesrevisited.htm|archivedate=November 21, 2007|df=mdy-all}} Even more so, those who are born intersex are forced to live unhappy lives full of surgery and scrutiny because they did not fit the standard model. In order to change the standard model, Sterling suggests that we should question, “should there be only two sexes?” ===''Sexing the Body''=== In chapter three of the book ''Sexing The Body'', titled "Of Gender and Genitals", Fausto-Sterling details the sexing of the human body. When an intersex child is first born, a "medical emergency" is called. Gender reassignment surgery is relied upon in order to "fix the problem" because the body must have a specific sex. Deciding whether to call a child a boy or a girl, then, employs social definitions of the essential components of gender. Fausto-Sterling describes the "Phall-o-metrics", the measurement technique used to determine medically acceptable penis or clitoris. Fausto-Sterling implies that the body is sexed and this sexing comes from the standards that society has placed on what a male and a female are supposed to look like and be. These definitions are primarily cultural, not biological.{{cite book|last=Fausto-Sterling|first=Anne|title=Sexing the Body: Gender Politics and the Construction of Sexuality|year=2000|publisher=Basic Books|location=New York|pages=44–77}} == Publications == '''Books''' *{{cite book |author=Fausto-Sterling, Anne |title=Myths of gender: biological theories about women and men |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |year=1992 |pages= |isbn=0-465-04792-0 |oclc= |doi=}} *{{cite book |author=Fausto-Sterling, Anne |title=[[Sexing the Body: Gender Politics and the Construction of Sexuality]] |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |year=2000 |pages= |isbn=0-465-07714-5 |oclc= |doi=}}{{citation|title=Hormone mistreatment (review of ''Sexing the Body'')|journal=The Women's Review of Books|date=April 1, 2000|last=Tiefer|first=Leonore|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62026221.html|subscription=yes}}.{{citation|title=In the realm of the sexes: biologist Anne Fausto-Sterling believes there are actually five distinct genders|journal=The Advocate|date=March 14, 2000|last=Bronski|first=Michael|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-60021921.html|subscription=yes}}.{{citation|title=Sexing the Body: Gender Politics and the Construction of Sexuality (Review)|journal=The Journal of Sex Research|volume=38|pages=75|date=February 1, 2001|last=Stanley|first=William B.|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-75820044.html|subscription=yes|doi=10.1080/00224490109552072}}. *{{cite book |author=Fausto-Sterling, Anne |title=Sex/Gender: Biology in a Social World |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |year=2012 |pages= |isbn=9780415881456 |oclc= |doi=}} '''Book Chapters''' *Fausto-Sterling, Anne (2014). ''"''Nature''".'' In C. R. Stimpson & G. Herdt (Eds), ''Critical Terms for the Study of Gender.'' University of Chicago Press. pp. 294-315. [[International Standard Book Number|ISBN]] [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:BookSources?isbn=978-0226774817 978-0226774817].{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/265641239_Nature|title=(PDF) Nature|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2018-11-21}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{Cite journal | last = Touraille | first = Priscille | others = Justin W. Gibson (translator) | title = On the critiques of the concept of sex: an interview with Anne Fausto-Sterling | journal = [[Differences (journal)|differences: A Journal of Feminist Cultural Studies]] | volume = 27 | issue = 1 | pages = 189–205 | publisher = [[Duke University Press]] | doi = 10.1215/10407391-3522805 | date = May 2016 | url = https://doi.org/10.1215/10407391-3522805 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} ==External links== * [http://www.annefaustosterling.com/ Anne Fausto-Sterling website] * [http://research.brown.edu/research/profile.php?id=1100924089 Fausto-Sterling at Brown Research] * [https://brown.edu/Faculty/COSTS/people/facultypage.php?id=1100924089 Brown University – faculty page] * [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Anne_Fausto-Sterling/publication/239657377_The_Five_Sexes_Why_Male_and_Female_are_not_Enough/links/00b7d525802a725b6b000000/The-Five-Sexes-Why-Male-and-Female-are-not-Enough.pdf The Five Sexes: Why Male and Female Are Not Enough] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120105184513/http://www.wpath.org/journal/www.iiav.nl/ezines/web/IJT/97-03/numbers/symposion/sterling.htm Sexing the Body: How Biologists Construct Human Sexuality] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130927132441/http://www.gendercentre.org.au/resources/polare-archive/archived-articles/a-conversation-with-anne-fausto-sterling.htm A Conversation with Anne Fausto-Sterling] * [https://library.brown.edu/collatoz/info.php?id=56/ Anne Fausto-Sterling Papers] - Pembroke Center Archives, Brown University {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fausto-Sterling, Anne}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:American sexologists]] [[Category:Biology of gender]] [[Category:Brown University faculty]] [[Category:Gender studies academics]] [[Category:LGBT rights activists from the United States]] [[Category:LGBT people from New York (state)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Scientists from New York City]] [[Category:Intersex and medicine]]

'''Arbitrary inference''' is a classic tenet of [[cognitive therapy]] created by [[Aaron T. Beck]] in 1979.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.academyofct.org/relationships/|title = Relationships - ACT|last = Dattilo|first = Frank|website = Academy of Cognitive Therapy|language = en-US|access-date =}}</ref> He defines the act of making an arbitrary inference as the process of drawing a conclusion without sufficient evidence, or without any evidence at all. In cases of [[Depression (differential diagnoses)|depression]], Beck found that individuals may be more prone to [[cognitive distortion]]s, and make arbitrary inferences more often. These inferences could be general and or in reference to the effectiveness of their medicine or treatment.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Cognitive Therapy of Depression|last = Beck|first = Aaron T.|publisher = Guilford Press|year = 1979|isbn = 9780898629194|location =|pages =}}</ref> Arbitrary inference is one of numerous specific cognitive distortions identified by Beck that can be commonly presented in people with anxiety, depression, and psychological impairments.<ref>{{Cite book|url = http://college.cengage.com/psychology/engler/personality_theories/7e/students/learn_more/ch16.html|title = Personality Theories: An Introduction|last = Engler|first = Barbara|last2 = Pomerantz|first2 = Andrew|publisher = Cengage Learning|year = 2005|isbn = 9780618496624|location =|pages =}}</ref>
== Examples == One member of a married couple who does not receive a text back from his or her significant other promptly could conclude, "He or she must be cheating", or someone who has been feeling down on a rainy day could conclude, "I have seasonal depression."
== See also == * [[Jumping to conclusions|Jumping to Conclusions]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Cognitive therapy]] [[Category:Inference]] [[Category:Ignorance]]
{{cognitive-psych-stub}}

{{See also|Berson (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox person | name = Arthur Josef Stanislaus Berson | image = Arthur Berson.jpg | alt = Portrait of Arthur Berson | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1859|08|06}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1942|12|03|1859|08|06}} | death_place = | nationality = German | other_names = | occupation = Meteorologist | years_active = | known_for = High-altitude scientific ballooning | notable_works = }}
'''Arthur Josef Stanislaus Berson''' (6 August 1859 – 3 December 1942) was a [[Germans|German]]<ref>[http://encyklopedia.pwn.pl/haslo/3876507/berson-artur.html Encyklopedia PWN - Berson Artur]</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Encyclopedia of Climate and Weather: Abs-Ero|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=av7q4N8Ib6sC&printsec=frontcover&dq=encyclopedia+of+climate&hl=pl&sa=X&ei=V4TgUdLYB8WROKbFgZAC&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=berson&f=false|accessdate=13 July 2013 |year=2011 |publisher= Oxford University Press|location=New York |isbn=978-0-19-976532-4 |page=457}}</ref> [[meteorologist]] and pioneer of [[aerology]] who was a native of Neu Sandez, [[Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galicia]] (now [[Nowy Sącz]], [[Poland]]).
After visiting the [[gymnasium (school)|gymnasium]] in Neu Sandez, Berson studied [[philology]] in [[University of Vienna|Vienna]]. He then studied [[meteorology]] and [[geography]] in [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Berlin]], where he had as instructors [[Ferdinand von Richthofen]] and [[Wilhelm von Bezold]]. In 1890 he was an assistant to meteorologist [[Richard Assmann|Richard Aßmann]] at the Meteorological Institute in Berlin. During this period of time he was also secretary of the ''Deutschen Verein zur Förderung der Luftschiffahrt'', the first [[aeronautics|aeronautical]] organization in Germany. In 1900 he became ''Hauptobservator'' at the newly founded Aeronautics Observatory in Berlin-[[Tegel]], and was later stationed at the Lindenberg Aeronautical Observatory in [[Beeskow]]. From 1896 to 1899 Berson was editor of the magazine ''Zeitschrift für Luftfahrt und Physik der Atmosphäre'' (Magazine for Aviation and Physics of the Atmosphere).
== Scientific research == Berson is largely known for his scientific hot-air balloon expeditions. On 4 December 1894, he ascended to a then-record altitude of 9,155 meters aboard the hydrogen balloon ''Phoenix''. On 10 January 1901, with artillery officer Alfred Hildebrandt (1870–1949), he travelled from Berlin to [[Markaryd]], [[Sweden]] in a balloon, thus being the first to cross the [[Baltic Sea]] by air. On 10 January 1902, with balloonist Hermann Elias (1876–1955), he set the German long-distance ballooning record, as the two men journeyed from Berlin to [[Poltava]] in the central [[Ukraine]] (1,470 kilometers in 30 hours).
During the 1890s, he was involved in international "simultaneous ascents" with balloonists from other nations. These ascents were performed in order to study variances of [[climate|climatic]] conditions above different locations in Europe, to work to bring about uniformity in methods of observation, and to create increased cooperation among nations in the new science of [[aerology]]. [[File:Assmann Berson.jpg|right|thumb|With Richard Aßmann; Berson at the right]] On 31 July 1901, with meteorologist [[Reinhard Süring]], he took his most celebrated ascent. Starting from Berlin-[[Tempelhof]] aboard the ''Preussen'', Berson and Süring ultimately reached a height of 10,800 meters above [[sea level]]. At 6000 m. they required compressed oxygen, at 10,000 m. both scientists were rendered unconscious, and after regaining consciousness were able to land their balloon near [[Briesen, Oder-Spree|Briesen]], 7.5 hours after their flight began. Their record ascent had significant scientific importance. Climatic data taken from simultaneously released unmanned [[Atmospheric sounding|sounding]] balloons agreed with the information gathered from the Berson/Süring ascent. Now scientists such as Richard Aßmann no longer had any reason to distrust temperature readings taken from unmanned balloons, an important factor that led to the discovery of the [[stratosphere]] by Aßmann and [[Teisserenc de Bort]] in 1902.
Another important aspect of high-altitude flight involved [[physiology|physiological]] problems that balloonists could experience when exposed to conditions at great heights. Here, Berson assisted physiologists [[Hermann von Schrötter]] and [[Nathan Zuntz]] with pioneer experiments in the field of [[aviation medicine]]. He undertook high-altitude balloon ascents with the two physiologists, and conducted studies of [[decompression sickness]] with a [[decompression chamber|pneumatic chamber]] located at the ''Jüdischen Krankenhaus'' (Jewish Hospital) in Berlin.
Other significant accomplishments by Berson include climatic studies with weather kites off of [[Svalbard]], pioneer meteorological observations from [[German East Africa]], and aerological research over the [[Amazon Basin]].
== Publications == * ''Wissenschaftliche luftfahrten, ausgeführt vom Deutschen verein zur förderung der luftschiffahrt in Berlin 1899-1900'' (with Richard Assmann; part of the series: Aeronautical collection. Folio group, v. 17) - Scientific air journeys, etc. * ''Beitrage zur erforschung der atmosphare mittels des luftballons'', 1900 (with Richard Assmann and others) - Contributions to the exploration of the atmosphere by means of balloons. * ''Hauptfahrten Nr. 33 und 34, die gleichzeitigen Fahrten vom 6. bis 7. Juli 1894 die 18. Fahrt des "Phönix" ; die 2. Fahrt des Registrirballons "Cirrus'', 1900 - The 18 July 1894 run of the "Phonix"; the second ride, the registrar balloons "Cirrus". * ''Ergebnisse der Arbeiten am Aëroautischen observatorium in den Jahren 1900 und 1901'' (with Richard Assmann), 1902 - Results of the work at the aeronautic observatory in the years 1900/01. * ''Bericht über die aerologische Expedition des Königlichen Aeronautischen Observatoriums nach Ostafrika im Jahre 1908'', 1910 - Report on the aerological expedition of the Royal Aeronautical Observatory to [[East Africa]] in 1908. * ''Die Vorbereitungen und die wissenschaftlichen Ergebnisse der Polarexpedition der "Italia"'', (with [[Umberto Nobile]] and others), 1929 - Preparations and scientific results of the polar expedition of the "Italia". * ''Die arktisfahrt des luftschiffes "Graf Zeppelin" im juli 1931; wissenschaftliche ergebnisse'', 1933 - The Arctic flight of the airship [[LZ 127 Graf Zeppelin|Graf Zeppelin]] in July 1931; scientific results.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-no95-17935 WorldCat Identities] (publications)</ref>
== References == * This article incorporates text based on a translation of an equivalent article at the [[German Wikipedia]]. * [http://saekular.pik-potsdam.de/en/allgemein/ballonfahrt_en.htm Süring and Berson's Balloon Ascenton 31 July 1901] {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * [https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1898/09/26/102123585.pdf Five miles up in a balloon] In: The New York Times, 26 September 1898, p 4.
{{Authority control}}

[[File:Dunedin recycling bins 2008.jpg|thumb|Blue box recycling bins]]
The '''blue box recycling system''' (BBRS) was initially a [[waste management]] system used by [[Canada|Canadian]] municipalities to collect source separated [[Municipal solid waste|household waste]] materials for the purpose of recycling. The first full-scale community wide BBRS was implemented in 1983 by the waste management contractor Ontario Total Recycling Systems Ltd. (a subsidiary of [[Laidlaw]] Waste Systems) for the [[Kitchener, Ontario|City of Kitchener]], Ontario. The blue box recycling system was implemented as part of the city's waste management procedures. The blue box system and variations of it remain in place in hundreds of cities around the world.
==Overview== Today, many municipalities operate blue box programs that accept all forms of paper materials, most plastic packaging, glass containers, [[aluminum can]]s and [[Tin can|steel cans]]. For example, the City of Greater Napanee accepts: * [[Glass Bottles|Glass bottles]] and jars, including all glass containers which previously contained a food or beverage product. * Metal food and beverage cans, including all hard shell steel or [[aluminum]] containers which previously contained a food or beverage product. * [[Aluminium foil|Aluminum foil]], meaning food wrap, food packaging and kitchenware such as pie plates made from a thin sheet of aluminum. * Rigid-shell plastic containers, including [[polyethylene terephthalate]] (PETE#I), high-density polyethylene (HDPE #2), [[low-density polyethylene]] (LDPE #4), polypropylene (PP #5) and polystyrene (PS #6), which previously contained a non-hazardous [[consumer product]]. * Rigid foam plastic containers. * Newspapers, magazines, flyers and household papers. * Old boxboard and old cardboard (non-waxed, flattened & bundled no larger than 30"x30"x8"). * Bundled [[plastic bag]]s (LDPE). * Other material as designated by the town from time to time.
The municipality provides the blue boxes to residents in areas serviced by the recycling program. This usually includes all [[single-family home]]s and townhouse units receiving [[Waste collection|garbage collection]]. Tenants of [[apartment building]]s typically do not use blue boxes but rather deposit their household recyclable materials in larger containers made available.
==History==
===Early stages=== An organization called Pollution Probe was formed in 1969 by students and faculty at the [[University of Toronto]] and in 1971, members published a report stressing the need for recycling. Also in 1971, the Canadian Federal Government first established a national Department of the Environment, known as [[Environment Canada]], with Environmental protection as one of its priorities. The Ontario government followed suit with a Ministry of the Environment in 1972.
Jack McGinnis of Toronto helped form a community-based non-profit organization called "Is Five" Foundation in 1974. Named for a book of poetry by [[e.e. cummings]], Is Five organized Canada’s first multi-material curbside pickup of recyclable material for 80,000 households of [[The Beaches]] neighbourhood of east [[Toronto]]. In 1977, Jack McGinnis and Derek Stephenson created a private consulting company, Resource Integration Systems (RIS) to advise governments in the field of recycling and waste management.
That same year, in response to the [[1973 energy crisis]], Rick Findlay was hired by Environment Canada’s Federal Facilities Program to develop and coordinate a resource conservation program primarily for federal government facilities in Ontario. The program was expected to improve environmental quality and reduce energy demand. The Federal Facilities Program sought advice on a recycling pilot program for [[Canadian Forces Base Borden]] and eventually made contact with RIS. RIS experimented with a variety of techniques to improve the performance recycling and found that participation rates were significantly higher when residents could simply drop their recycling in a plastic box. Initially, the project at CFB Borden used milk crates borrowed from a local grocery store. Participation was likely encouraged by a standing order from the Base Commander to recycle.
Meanwhile, a student and a volunteer at a [[Kitchener, Ontario|Kitchener]]/[[Waterloo, Ontario]] office of Pollution Probe, Eric Hellman organized "Garbage Fest 77" in Kitchener to raise awareness about the consequences of garbage production. McGinnis was invited to speak about his experiences with the CFB Borden program. Hellman also requested a representative from Superior Sanitation (later to be Laidlaw Waste Systems Ltd), the local garbage collection contractor, and an employee named Nyle Ludolph attended Garbage Fest. After meeting McGinnis at the festival, Ludolph became an enthusiastic recycler at his own home and helped increase Laidlaw’s presence in recycling. Nyle managed "Total Recycling Systems", a subsidiary of Superior Sanitation/Laidlaw.
In 1978, Jack McGinnis and Eric Hellman and others met in the basement of the Trinity United Church on Yonge Street in Toronto and created the Recycling Council of Ontario.
===Implementation=== In 1981, after close cooperation with Nyle Ludolph, RIS submitted a proposal to Laidlaw to collect and recycle materials at the curbside for a pilot project in Kitchener, Ontario. Lillian and Ken Croal of Kitchener were the first to use and receive a blue box. RIS designed the program, and Total Recycling had the responsibility to handle all operations. The Kitchener project included 1,500 households and was tested with four different approaches to recycling: * Curbside pick-up without providing blue boxes; * Curbside pick-up with blue boxes; * Curbside pick-up with blue boxes, including knocking on doors to inform residents; and, * Composting with composters provided by Laidlaw, free of charge.
The blue box recycling system was proposed to be included as an included “extra” to the regular waste management contract. Laidlaw was successful in obtaining the waste management contract for Kitchener, and the blue box system had its commercial launch. RIS came up with the slogan “We Recycle”, which was applied to every box that went out in Kitchener. Various reasons why the boxes were coloured blue, as opposed to some other colour have been posited: the facts are that RIS felt they looked best and were most visible in blue. It was also a colour that was suitable in terms of withstanding damage from ultraviolet light.
The four recycling approaches were monitored by RIS for one year and the blue box was decided as the most effective. The “test project” continued to run however, and people who did not have the blue boxes began requesting them. Laidlaw received many letters from residents expressing support for the program and for it to continue. The blue box program was implemented citywide in 1983, with Laidlaw providing the extra investment in additional boxes and trucks and handling equipment even though it was not required by their waste management contract with the City. Participation rates ran at 85 percent, and the program was regarded as a success.
In 1984 the Citywide contract for Kitchener went out to public bid, as previously scheduled. City staff simply followed previous procedures – i.e., no specific requirement to offer recycling services was included in bid documents. Laidlaw chose to submit a bid that included continuation of the blue box service while their competitors, mainly large US-based firms, did not. One such competitor submitted a bid that was about $400,000 lower than the one from Laidlaw. The Council meeting where the decision was made was filled with local citizens, especially students, asking their City to support the blue box. The City did, voting to take the blue box bid, not the low bid.
In 1985, Laidlaw won the bid for recycling in the City of Mississauga and introduced the second commercial blue box program in Ontario in June 1986, the largest recycling effort in North America.
Between 1997 and 1999, Laidlaw, Inc. exited the solid waste business after incurring heavy losses through its investments in [[Safety-Kleen]] and Greyhound Lines. After almost 20 years of expansion, Laidlaw Inc. filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code in June 2001.
Currently in Ontario, Canada industry compensates municipalities for approximately 50% of the net costs to operate the blue box program.<ref name=Mueller2013/>
The blue box system and variations of it remain in place in hundreds of cities around the world.
==See also== * {{portal-inline|Canada}} * {{portal-inline|Sustainable development}}
==References== * Humphries, Dianne N. (1997). [https://books.google.com/books?id=6sbzGgAACAAJ ''We recycle' – The Creators of the Blue Box Program'']. Pollution Probe. * {{cite web | url=http://www.solidwastemag.com/news/blue-box-family-feud/1000202954/ | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130203023126/http://www.solidwastemag.com/news/blue-box-family-feud/1000202954/ | dead-url=yes | archive-date=February 3, 2013 | title=Blue Box Family Feud | publisher=Solid Waste & Recycling Magazine | date=April 1, 2006 | accessdate=May 4, 2012 | author=Crittenden, Guy }} * {{cite web | url=http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/toronto/story.html?id=9c4187a3-a14b-4e5f-bc9b-c11803495ee7 | title=Blue-box recycling system to get facelift | publisher=''National Post'' | date=September 12, 2006 | accessdate=May 4, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304091835/http://www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/toronto/story.html?id=9c4187a3-a14b-4e5f-bc9b-c11803495ee7 | archivedate=March 4, 2016 | df= }} * {{cite web | url=http://www.cityofkingston.ca/pdf/waste/recycling/WasteRecyclingStrategy_2010-2013.pdf | title=Waste Recycling Strategy: 2010{{ndash}}2013 | publisher=City of Kingston, Solid Waste Division | date=December 14, 2010 | accessdate=May 4, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111119041525/http://www.cityofkingston.ca/pdf/waste/recycling/WasteRecyclingStrategy_2010-2013.pdf | archivedate=November 19, 2011 | df= }} * {{cite web | url=http://www.bclocalnews.com/news/134467933.html | title=Cities question package recycling plan | publisher=BC Local News| date=November 30, 2011 | accessdate=May 4, 2012 | author=Nagel, Jeff}}
===Citations=== {{Reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=Mueller2013>{{cite journal|last=Mueller|first=William|title=The effectiveness of recycling policy options: Waste diversions or just diversions?|journal=Waste Management|year=2013|volume=33|issue=3|pages=508–518|doi=10.1016/j.wasman.2012.12.007}}<!--|accessdate=11 November 2013--></ref> }}
==External links== * {{cite web | url=http://www.ene.gov.on.ca/environment/en/subject/waste_diversion/STDPROD_078594.html | title=Waste Diversion: Blue Box}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.regionofwaterloo.ca/en/aboutTheEnvironment/Blue_Box_Recycling.asp | title=Blue Box Recycling}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120423145305/http://www.winnipeg.ca/waterandwaste/recycle/bluebox.stm Blue Box Recycling]{{spaced ndash}} City of Winnipeg, Canada * [http://www.sustain-ability.ca/blue-box-story.php The Blue Box Story]{{spaced ndash}} Durham Sustain Ability (Canada)

[[Category:Waste containers]] [[Category:Recycling]]

'''[[Caste]] systems in Africa''' are a form of social stratification found in numerous ethnic groups, found in over fifteen countries, particularly in the [[Sahel]], [[West Africa]]n and [[North Africa]]n region.{{cite journal|author=Tal Tamari| year= 1991|title= The Development of Caste Systems in West Africa| journal= The Journal of African History| volume= 32| number= 2| pages= 221–250|publisher= Cambridge University Press| jstor= 182616| doi=10.1017/s0021853700025718}}, '''Quote:''' "Castes, endogamous artisan and musician groups, are characteristic of over fifteen West African peoples, inhabiting at least fourteen states. They are found among the Soninke, the various Manding-speaking populations (including the Bambara, Malinke and Khassonke), the Wolof, Tukulor, Senufo, Minianka, Dogon, Songhay, and most Fulani, Moorish and Tuareg populations". These caste systems feature endogamy, hierarchical status, inherited occupation, membership by birth, pollution concepts and restraints on commensality. The specifics of the caste systems in Africa vary among the ethnic groups. Some societies have a rigid and strict caste system with embedded slavery, whereas others are more diffuse and complex. Countries in [[Africa]] that have societies with caste systems include [[Mali]], [[Mauritania]], [[Senegal]], [[Gambia]], [[Guinea]], [[Ivory Coast]], [[Niger]], [[Burkina Faso]], [[Cameroon]], [[Liberia]], [[Sudan]], [[Sierra Leone]], [[Algeria]], [[Nigeria]], [[Chad]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Somalia]], [[Djibouti]], [[Eritrea]] and others.[https://books.google.com/books?id=V4DEXhUF9csC&pg=PA9 ''Human Rights Watch''] Page 9. While it is unclear when and how the caste systems developed in Africa, they are not ancient and likely developed sometime between the 9th century and 15th century in various ethnic groups, probably in conjunction with the institution of slavery.Tal Tamari (2005), Kingship and Caste in Africa: History, Diffusion and Evolution, Editor: Declan Quigley in The Character of Kingship, Berg, {{ISBN|978-184-520-2910}}, pages 141-169 ==East Africa== ===Amhara people=== {{main|Amhara people}} The social stratification of the [[Amhara people]] of [[Ethiopia]] includes castes. According to [[Donald N. Levine|Donald Levine]] – a professor of Sociology specializing in Ethiopian society, the Amhara society has consisted of high-ranking clans, low-ranking clans, caste groups (artisans), and slaves. The Amhara caste system was hierarchically higher than its lowest slaves strata. The Amhara caste system consisted of: (1) endogamy, (2) hierarchical status, (3) restraints on commensality, (4) pollution concepts, (5) each caste has had a traditional occupation, and (6) inherited caste membership.{{cite book|author=Donald N.
